results.notes:
Code: Bot_1167/2018_DSC05248

Habitat: light, mixed predominantly conifer wood, Picea abies dominant with intermixed Fagus sylvatica; slightly inclined mountain slope, northwest aspect; near river bed; humid and mostly shady place; exposed to direct rain, average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-8 deg C, elevation 575 m (1.900 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: heavily rotten stump of a larger Picea abies.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, next to Soča trail, left bank of river Soča, between farm house Fačar and Maselc, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Neoantrodia serialis is a quite common and conspicuous polypore, sometimes forming large basidiocarps, which can extend up to 2 m in length (Ref.: 1). It is quite variable in habit, sometimes forming large groups of small crowded pilei, sometimes it is almost without them. When growing resupinate it can be very similar to Heterobasidion annosum and only microscopy of spores can separate both with confidence.

Two largely effused-reflexed fruit bodies were present; larger basidiocarp’s dimension 20 × 7 cm, trama leathery up to 3 mm thick, tubes on vertical parts up to 4-5 mm long; pilei up to 22 × 7 mm and up to 6 mm off the substratum, often confluent; SP none (no spores found – too young basidiocarps?).

Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Sony ILCE6000 / Carl Zeiss Vario-Tessar E 16-70mm/ f4
results.location_name: Lower Trenta Valley, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia

Habitat: Mixed wood, Fagus sylvatica, Picea abies, Fraxinus ornus, Ostrya carpinifolia dominant trees; moderately inclined mountain slope, south aspect; relatively warm place; cretaceous clastic rock (flysh) bedrock, partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 8-10 deg C, elevation 525 m (1.750 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: on bark of still standing, dead and rotten, partly decorticated Fagus sylvatica.

Place: Bovec basin, east of Bovec, below Visna settlement, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Habit of the fungus on this pictures and substratum fit well to Jackrogersella cohaerens (Annulohypoxylon cohaerens). But several other taxa can be very similar. For example: Jackrogersella minutella (former Hypoxylon cohaerens var. microsporum) and Jackrogersella multiformis (former Annulohypoxylon multiforme) and a few others can have similar stromatal features. Microscopy is needed for a reliable determination. Tentative field identification often relies on host. Jackrogersella minutella is restricted to Quercus and Castanea, Jackrogersella multiformis grows mostly on Betula, Alnus and Corylus and Jackrogersella cohaerens is restricted to Fagus sylvatica. However, host specificity is rarely absolute. Since no microscopy was done for this observation, the determination remains unreliable.

Ref.:
(1) https://www.123pilze.de/... (accessed Dec. 22. 2018)
(2) http://pyrenomycetes.free.fr/... (accessed Dec. 22.2018)
(3) M.W.Beug, A.E. Bessette, A.R. Bessette, Ascomycete Fungi of North America, Uni.of Texas Press, Austin (2014), p 281.
(4)
https://www.mycoquebec.org/... (accessed Dec. 22.2018)

Nikon D70 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

results.notes:
Growing on a hardwood stick. Resupinate with fimbriate edges. Hymenium pinkish to yellowish to white. Merulioid to even. All structures inamyloid. Monomitic with simple-septate generative hyphae. All structures inamyloid. Hyphidia absent. Cystidia rare. Cystidia hymenial, projecting, tubular, thin-walled and not encrusted. One cystidium measured at 43.47 × 4.48 µm. Spores smooth, thin-walled and cylindrical with some slightly curved. Spore measurements from Piximetre: (3.8) 3.9 – 4.9 (5.7) × (1.5) 1.8 – 2.1 (2.2) µm, Q = (1.8) 2 – 2.7 (2.8); N = 30, Me = 4.4 × 2 µm; Qe = 2.3
Individual spores: 4.44 × 1.76 µm, 4.42 × 2.13 µm, 4.35 × 2.13 µm, 4.92 × 2.19 µm, 4.45 × 1.96 µm, 4.92 × 2.06 µm, 4.62 × 1.92 µm, 5.29 × 1.96 µm, 4.58 × 1.98 µm, 4.16 × 2.03 µm, 3.78 × 1.78 µm, 4.09 × 1.86 µm, 4.68 × 1.99 µm, 5.66 × 2.08 µm, 4.60 × 2.13 µm, 4.53 × 1.90 µm, 4.13 × 1.84 µm, 4.18 × 2.00 µm, 3.98 × 1.92 µm, 4.00 × 2.18 µm, 5.14 × 1.86 µm, 4.64 × 2.09 µm, 4.14 × 1.94 µm, 4.03 × 1.52 µm, 3.75 × 1.87 µm, 4.31 × 1.99 µm, 3.85 × 1.96 µm, 4.18 × 1.90 µm, 4.06 × 1.93 µm, 3.94 × 1.88 µm

results.notes: In mixed Alnus rubra/Acer macrophyllum canopy. A very healthy location here in Thurston County(at least in terms of air quality). I always love visiting this spot due to the fact that my eagle scout project in 1994 was a wetland restoration of Woodard Creek, which directly feeds into Woodard bay. The health of both locations since organizing the clearance of Scotch broom and introduction of Salix, Thuja, Alnus rubra and others has pulled the clogged bank of Woodard creek and opened up the possibility for lush habitat, and thus, the brackish/estuarian Woodard bay is a more diverse, lush and hospitable habitat for native wildlife to thrive. Flyers and info cards(along with the porcelain coated sign) are still stocked biennially near Mother Joseph Care center in Lacey where my Restoration project of Woodard Creek begins. The proliferation of Lobaria spp. here makes me even more pleased as they are a great air quality indicator.

results.notes:
Collected by Maricel Pation near 280 Old Tuckerton Rd., which is to the south east of Chatsworth. This is a disjunct piece of FPP land. The habitat was reported to be wet. Birch had to be present, but was not observed/not paid attention to.
Cap “footprint” = 4.5 cm wide; cap flesh = ~1.5 cm thick above the stipe; tubes = 1.2 cm deep; stipe length = at least 11.5 cm long; stipe width = 6 mm near apex, 9 mm wide max in the middle. The cap surface had some faint greenish hues. The stipe base was not extracted whole, but one can see faint bluing in that area in the cross-section pic. No reddening of the exposed flesh was detected. To my knowledge this is the first collection of this kind (i.e., sect./subsect. Scabra) made in FPP.

Multiple growths on 2 cut logs near each other by side of trail and believe they are all same species. Top soft and velvety feel. Pores very large. The bark looks like it may be a Fremont Cottonwood (no leaves in vicinity) and do not think it is oak or willow.
On Calif Mushroom ID Forum, this was identified as most likely Inocutis, maybe Inonotus,or Inonotopsis (Chael Thomas).

Pileus: depressed in shape, white overall with central darkening (to cinnamon shade) . Covered in thick, clear, “goopy” slime. Margin is pubescent.

Odor/Flavor: Indistinct to pleasant (slight flowery notes)

Spore print: white

KOH—>negative on all parts
Does not bruise or stain

results.notes:
Several small to medium mushrooms and one very large (> 5" across) that appear to be Gymnopilus Luteofolius. Found on large wood chips (not sure of type) and dead leaves on a shaded hill by train tracks.

Many of the mushrooms have blue-green spots on the caps, and the very large one on the stipe, too. These spots were already present—they are not from bruising/damage.

I’m not really sure these are Gymnopilus Luteofolius—the very large specimen has yellow, not orange, gills, and my understanding is that very mature specimens should have orange gills.
results.location_name: Berkeley, Alameda Co., California, USA

results.notes: Growing on a hardwood stick, likely Cercis canadensis. Effused-reflexed white distinct margins and appearing to be perennial. All structures inamyloid. Dimitic with clamped generative hyphae. Hyphidia absent. Heavily encrusted lamprocystidia abundant, projecting 47.55 µm to 137.72 µm (33 measured). Cystidia hyaline to yellowish or brownish. Complete cystidia were difficult to measure but cystidia were measured at up to 205.77 µm long and 22.85 µm wide. Spores hyaline, thin-walled and smooth. Spore measurements: (8.3) 8.8 – 11.4 (12.3) × (5.7) 6.3 – 7.8 (8.5) µm, Q = (1.2) 1.24 – 1.6 (1.8); N = 26, Me = 10 × 7.1 µm; Qe = 1.4
results.location_name: Cope Environmental Center, Centerville, Indiana, USA

results.notes:
Growing on a fallen conifer stick. Either Pinus or Picea. All structures inamyloid. Monomitic with clamped generative hyphae. Cystidia absent. Basidia urniform and 6-sterigmate. Spores smooth, thin-walled and prominently apiculate. Spore measurements from Piximetre: (5) 5.2 – 5.8 (6.1) × (2.1) 2.2 – 2.6 µm, Q = (2) 2.1 – 2.46 (2.5); N = 8, Me = 5.5 × 2.4 µm; Qe = 2.3
Individual spores: 5.84 × 2.62 µm, 5.24 × 2.27 µm, 5.48 × 2.23 µm, 6.06 × 2.51 µm, 5.03 × 2.55 µm, 5.47 × 2.15 µm, 5.52 × 2.60 µm, 5.31 × 2.44 µm

results.notes:
Growing on a Pinus strobus log. Associated with a brown rot. Drying to a dingy yellow. Odor not distinctive. Releasing brownish oil droplets in Melzer’s reagent. Monomitic with clamped generative hyphae. Subicular hyphae brown. Hymenial hyphae hyaline. Cystidia hyphoid and abundant, leptocystidia. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores strongly amyloid, smooth and thin-walled, many sticking together in clusters of 2 to 4. Spore measurements: (5.3) 5.5 – 7.3 (7.9) × (1.9) 2 – 2.7 (2.9) µm, Q = (2.2) 2.3 – 3.4 (3.9); N = 30, Me = 6.3 × 2.3 µm; Qe = 2.8

results.notes:
This species is very appealing to me. In the first years dedicated to mushroom observation I found very many species of the genus Entoloma. One of them, that I didn’t know to exist here, was precisely E. bloxamii. At the time my friend Luis Morgado was preparing a paper about this species and related or similar ones (L. Morgado et al 2013), particularly one from North America, which was sometimes also named as E. bloxamii. That specimen of E. bloxamii found by me in December 17, 2011, was included in the studies made during the preparation of the manuscript and appear there as LNM 171211 (L), in the additional collections examined of that species.
One week later of that first observation I found a second specimen, but since then I was not able to find it again until last week, thus more or less 7 years later, though every year by Christmas time I spent some periods looking for it again.
Meanwhile, the North American part of E. bloxamii, was named as E. medianox by C.F. Schwarz in 2015.
Attached to this observation you can found the photos with the three specimens found this time.
The material of the 2011 observations was published in a portuguese forum, but presently the photos are lacking. Therefore, I will creat two observations with that original material.

results.notes: Very small, densely branched corals(dingy yellow 1-3cm) fruiting from the roots of a mature Douglas fir. Densely packed in small tufts/mats in needle litter and debris. Dried multiple specimens on a slide for microscopy(see added images). Spore print=yellow. Strongly farinaceous odor to fresh material. Spores are very small, semi-ellipsoid and smooth(not spiny). Dingy yellow cast(not gelatinous, nor orange and fragile) leads far from the possibility of Ramariopsis crocea or Clavulinopsis corniculata. Nomenclatural notes on this species being Ramaria curta still seem to be up in the air from many different databases. The most recent posts on MO of the species are listed as Phaeoclavulina curta(which I placed/labeled this collection). Multiple dried fruiting bodies available=bagged, labeled in home herbarium. Microscopy images included..
